definition[0]: a change that is caused by an event, action etc
example[0]: This ingredient also has the effect of making your skin look younger.
example[1]: A system failure has a knock-on effect throughout the whole hotel.
example[2]: the cumulative effect of human activities on the global environment
example[3]: A much lower dose of the painkiller can still produce the desired effect.
example[4]: In mental illness, there is a complex relationship between cause and effect.
example[5]: My parents’ divorce had a big effect on me.
example[6]: the harmful effects of modern farming practices
example[7]: the long-term effects of the drug
example[8]: I could feel the effects of the thin mountain air.
definition[1]: if a law, rule, or system takes effect or comes into effect, it officially starts
definition[2]: if a law, rule, or system is in effect, it is being used now
definition[3]: an idea or feeling that an artist, speaker, book etc tries to make you think of or to feel
example[9]: Turner’s paintings give an effect of light.
definition[4]: an unusual or impressive sound or image that is artificially produced for a film, play, or radio programme
example[10]: Eating junk food will eventually have an effect on your health.
collocation[1]: have the effect of doing something
example[11]: The news had the effect of making everyone feel better.
example[12]: If we combine these sounds, they produce an effect that is almost jazzy.
example[13]: Small companies will feel the effect of the recession first.
example[14]: The government must take action to reduce the effects of pollution.
example[15]: Lower mortgage rates will cushion the effect of rising house prices.
example[16]: The effect of the drug lasts about six hours.
example[17]: The effect of the anaesthetic was beginning to wear off.
example[18]: The teachers’ strike had a big effect on many schools.
example[19]: Global warming could have a significant effect on agriculture in many parts of the world.
example[20]: My father’s death had a profound effect on me.
example[21]: Taking the new drug had a dramatic effect on his health.
example[22]: The drugs have a relatively small effect on a lot of patients.
example[23]: The advertising campaign had a negligible effect on demand.
example[24]: The announcement had an immediate effect on stock prices.
example[25]: Inflation can sometimes have some good effects on the economy.
example[26]: The incident had a very positive effect on his career.
example[27]: Working too hard was beginning to have a bad effect on my health.
example[28]: the negative effects of low rainfall
example[29]: the harmful effects of drinking too much alcohol
example[30]: Some of the effects can be quite damaging.
example[31]: He drank five beers, but they did not seem to have any visible effect on him.
example[32]: No one told them about the adverse effects of smoking marijuana.
example[33]: Many boxers suffer with the long-term effects of punches to the head.
example[34]: The strike could have a knock-on effect at other airports.
example[35]: The cumulative effect of these policies will be to push up inflation.
example[36]: His team talk had the desired effect because the team went on to win the game.
example[37]: We won’t know the full effect of the tax changes until the end of the financial year.
example[38]: His words seemed to have a calming effect on the crowd.
example[39]: The people in this area are still suffering from the effects of the famine.
example[40]: The treatment had little or no effect.
definition[5]: an effect that happens as a result of something important, especially a big and permanent effect
example[41]: Changes in technology have had a massive impact on the way we work.
example[42]: the environmental impact of industrial activity
definition[6]: the effect that something has on people’s opinions or behaviour, or on how something develops
example[43]: American television has had a big influence on popular culture in the west.
example[44]: His ideas had a lot of influence at the time.
definition[7]: an unwanted and unplanned effect that something has – used especially about drugs and medical treatment
example[45]: Common side effects of the drug may include headaches and muscle pains.
definition[8]: bad effects that continue for a long time after the thing that caused them
example[46]: A traumatic experience can have severe psychological after-effects.
definition[9]: the effects that happen later as a result of an event or decision, especially a range of effects that continue for a long time
example[48]: The scandal could have serious repercussions for her career.
example[49]: The judge’s decision is likely to have important repercussions for future cases of this kind.
definition[10]: used when something has an effect on something, which then has an effect on something else
example[50]: Higher oil prices have a knock-on effect on other fuels.
definition[11]: the effect that human activities have on the environment, caused by using up its natural resources, pollution, waste etc
example[51]: Businesses all over the world must attempt to reduce their environmental footprint.
example[52]: The house has a low carbon footprint (=it uses very little energy from carbon and therefore is good for the environment).
example[53]: Many parents lack confidence in their ability to effect change in their children’s behaviour.
definition[13]: the way in which an action, event, or person changes someone or something
example[54]: Inflation is having a disastrous effect on the economy.
definition[14]: to make a plan or idea happen
example[55]: It won’t be easy to put the changes into effect.
definition[15]: if a new arrangement, law, system etc comes into effect or takes effect, it officially starts
example[56]: The new tax rates come into effect in April.
definition[16]: starting to happen immediately, or from a particular date
example[57]: Mr Hoskins is appointed manager, with immediate effect.
example[58]: Insurance also covers personal effects required during travel on company business.
example[59]: You must obtain your client’s approval of the estate agent’s fees before you effect payment of them.
